body: I am also having a problem with this right now because I am using jQuery tmpl which uses ${variable}, so if you stick a(href="${url}') into jade and then try to convert that to a template you are out of luck unless you modify jQuery tmpl's regex to look for the escaped context.
Got the same problem with Underscore.js's templates. Any progress in this direction?

@1Marc the end result with that is that you want `a(href=${url})`? some stuff like this may never happen, we can't easily accommodate for every possible template engine, while maintaining js expressions for attrs etc
@visionmedia maybe it's possible to implement escape support inside attribute value as universal solution? Something like `option(value: "\<%= company.id %\>")`.
i originally chose `!=` because it looks really bad so it's more explicit haha, but for attrs `a(foo!: bar)` and `a(foo!= bar)` would work I suppose, supes ugly but hey haha
This one bit me too, using JSRender templates. I ended up dropping down to raw HTML for those tags.

(Just to add some fun: I opened this issue when I was trying to use jade to build **PHP** scripts.)

Mixing templates languages will always lead to hassles.

Is there any way to address this? I'm trying to use to use backbone.js with jade.
I want to be able to do:

``` jade
a(href='<%= url %>')
```

But it currently escapes it.

I'm surprised no one stumbled into this problem before. URLs that have ampersands are not unheard of, and are required by many systems and APIs. The current state disables me from calling the Google Maps API, for example.

Can I confirm that instead of calling:
script(src= 'http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?key=YOUR_API_KEY&sensor=false', type= 'text/javascript')

I simply just use the following?
"< script type="text/javascript" src="http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?key=YOUR_API_KEY&sensor=false">< /script >"

Ran into this today...seems that the best solution to change the underscore delimiters to mustache-style...

http://documentcloud.github.com/underscore/#template

TJ â€“ thanks for all of your work on this. Love using the Jade/Express/Stylus/CoffeeScript combo, but Underscore templates remain important for two reasons:
1. Tie to Backbone framework: if I'm already downloading Underscore, and it's written by same author, has compatibility, etc, would prefer to use it.
2. Speed. Most tests show that Resig templates are fastest, while Underscore seems to be somewhere near second.
underscore templates _are_ resig's templates, he just took that same code

Any chance this is going to be fixed soon? 

I like the `<%= foo %>` syntax, and I have all of my underscore templates using that. But i need to be able to create attributes that are not HTML encoded.
yeah I could add this right away, but just warning you guys it will be ugly :D `!="string"`

I'm good with that. :)

FYI - for now, I'm dropping back to plain HTML in my specific case:

`|<option value="<%= foo %>"> <%= bar %> </option>`

This is working for me for now, but I'd much prefer to see a `!=` to unescape values.
note that this also slightly bloats templates since they need to pass an escape map to attrs()
